head.title: Gas Prices Fall Nearly a Nickel

hedline.hl1: Gas Prices Fall Nearly a Nickel

block.p: Lower winter demand and higher oil supplies sent the average price of gasoline down nearly 5 cents nationwide in the last two weeks, almost to its price before Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, the Lundberg Survey reported today.
The average price of all grades of gasoline at full- and self-service stations, including taxes, was $1.20 a gallon on Friday, according to the biweekly survey of more than 13,000 stations.
Gasoline prices have dropped 4.97 cents since Feb. 8. The average price stood at $1.17 before the Aug. 2 invasion.
Gas prices peaked at $1.47 a gallon on Oct. 19. Prices have since fallen an average of 21.8 cents a gallon despite a 5-cent Federal gasoline tax that took effect on Dec. 1.

At self-service stations, which account for more than 80 percent of sales, the average price of regular unleaded gasoline was $1.07 a gallon on Friday. Premium unleaded was $1.23 a gallon, and regular leaded was $1.04.
At full-service stations, regular unleaded sold for $1.39 a gallon, premium unleaded for $1.53 and regular leaded for $1.38.
